description: From Latin nummulus (“(small amount of) money”) + English -ar (suffix forming adjectives with the sense ‘of, pertaining to, or near’). Nummulus is the diminutive of nummus (“a coin; piece of money”) + -ulus (diminutive suffix); while nummus is from Doric Greek νοῦμμος (noûmmos), from Ancient Greek νόμος (nómos, “kind of coin”), from νέμω (némō, “to deal out, dispense, distribute”) (from Proto-Indo-European *nem- (“to distribute; to give; to take”)) + -ος (-os, suffix forming nouns).

adjectives.description: nummular (comparative more nummular, superlative most nummular)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) Of or relating to coins or money.

definitionGroups.group: (by extension) Flattened with a rounded form, as a disc; coin-shaped.

entries.meaning: (pathology) Characterized by lesions (especially on the cornea or skin) which are round with well-defined borders.
(pathology, obsolete) Of sputum: forming flat, round shapes (formerly thought to be a symptom of tuberculosis).
